Award.AwardTitle: Tuning, sensitivity, and nonlinear dynamics in systems of coupled hair cells
Award.AbstractNarration: The sense of hearing remains one of the least understood of the senses, in terms of the underlying biophysical mechanisms. To be sensitive to extremely faint sounds, the auditory system must detect movements at a scale comparable to atomic dimensions. This involves hair cells--specialized cells that detect mechanical signals from incoming sound waves and convert them into electrical signals sent to the brain. This research will measure movements of hair cells to test the hypothesis that coupling between hair cells constitutes an important factor in achieving this auditory sensitivity and to explore the role of synchronization in the sensitivity of the whole organ. Internal auditory organs from the frog and the lizard will be placed in appropriate chemical environments, and images of their movements will be captured with a high-speed camera. By observing the motion of multiple hair cells in parallel, it will be possible to see if they move in unison. Additional measurements will test whether the coupled system shows a response that does not grow linearly with the signal. Finally, comparative study between organs of different species, which show very different geometry, will determine how different amounts of coupling affect the overall performance. The prediction is that synchronization among hair bundles will enhance both the sensitivity and tuning in the inner ear. If true, this will help to explain the nanoscale sensitivity of hearing, one of the long-open problems in sensory neuroscience. The project will provide educational opportunities for undergraduate and high school students, by involving them in highly interdisciplinary science projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Auditory and vestibular systems constitute examples of biological sensors that perform extremely sensitive mechanical detection. In this project, the PI pursued the hypothesis that synchronization among hair bundles constitutes one of the main components in achieving this sensitivity. Experiments were designed to compare the response characteristics of individual hair cells and those in which the bundles remain coupled to the overlying structures.

 

Our laboratory developed techniques allowing us to perform parallel imaging of multiple hair bundles in parallel, both when decoupled and when connected to the overlying membrane. We applied this method to study motion of hair cells in the amphibian sacculus and the basilar papilla of the Tokay gecko. Mechanical stimulation was applied with glass fibers or magnetic nanoparticles, and the evoked response was measured optically. The results allowed us to assess the impact of coupling on the overall response of the system. The experimental findings were supplemented with theoretical modeling, to further elucidate the differences attributable to the coupling.

 

We found that in the amphibian sacculus, frequency dispersion among hair cells – which can be quite substantial – leads to a highly sensitive but broadband response. The theoretical models indicated that the coupled system could exhibit qualitatively different dynamics than the constituent elements. Importantly, the coupled system exhibits robustness in the presence of noise: its sensitivity is not only not degraded but in a certain regime improved by the presence of noise, in a phenomenon known as stochastic resonance. Finally our experimental results on the coupled system showed the presence of a chaotic attractor in the underlying dynamics. The possible role of chaos in achieving the sensitivity of detection awaits further studies.

 

The techniques developed in these experiments, including  motion-tracking of nanometer-scale deflections, with sub-millisecond time resolution, performed on multiple elements in parallel, can be readily generalized to other fields in biology. The research was also closely connected to the PI’s education efforts, as it provided an opportunity for undergraduates and high school students to participate in research programs, and learn about inter-disciplinary fields of science. Particular emphasis was devoted to encouraging young women to pursue careers in science.
